sections.title: Eavestrough Systems Overview
sections.summary: Understanding eavestrough types, sizing, and material selection for NB climate.
sections.content_md:
## Eavestrough Systems Overview

### Purpose of Eavestroughs

Eavestroughs (gutters) collect roof runoff and direct it away from:
- Foundation walls
- Basement/crawlspace
- Landscaping and walkways
- Siding and exterior finishes

### Material Options

| Material | Lifespan | Cost | Pros | Cons |
|----------|----------|------|------|------|
| **Aluminum** | 20-30 yrs | $$ | Light, no rust, many colors | Dents, expands |
| **Vinyl** | 10-20 yrs | $ | DIY-friendly, no rust | Brittle in cold, sags |
| **Steel** | 20-30 yrs | $$ | Strong, holds shape | Can rust, heavy |
| **Copper** | 50+ yrs | $$$$ | Beautiful, durable | Expensive, patinas |
| **Zinc** | 40+ yrs | $$$ | Self-healing, durable | Cost |

> **Zone 6 Recommendation:** Aluminum is the most common choice - durable, affordable, and performs well in freeze-thaw cycles. Vinyl should be avoided in NB due to brittleness in cold.

### Profile Types

**K-Style (Ogee):**
- Most common residential profile
- Decorative front face
- Available in 5" and 6" widths
- Handles more water than half-round

**Half-Round:**
- Traditional/historic appearance
- Easier to clean
- Less capacity than K-style
- Often used with copper

**Box/Commercial:**
- Maximum capacity
- Used for large roof areas
- Industrial appearance

### Sizing Guidelines

| Roof Area | Minimum Gutter | Minimum Downspout |
|-----------|----------------|-------------------|
| Up to 600 sq ft | 5" K-style | 2" x 3" |
| 600-1000 sq ft | 5" K-style | 3" x 4" |
| Over 1000 sq ft | 6" K-style | 3" x 4" or 4" round |

**One downspout per 40 linear feet of gutter maximum**

sections.title: Installation Fundamentals
sections.summary: Proper slope, hanger spacing, and installation techniques for reliable performance.
sections.content_md:
## Installation Fundamentals

### Slope Requirements

**Proper Slope:**
- Minimum 1/16" per foot toward downspout
- Recommended 1/8" per foot for heavy rain areas
- Maximum run: 40 feet to single downspout

**Setting Slope:**
1. Mark high point at gutter start
2. Calculate drop (length x slope)
3. Mark low point at downspout
4. Snap chalk line between points
5. Install hangers along line

**Example:** 32' gutter run at 1/8" per foot
- Drop = 32 x 0.125 = 4 inches total
- High end 4" above low end

### Hanger Types & Spacing

| Hanger Type | Best For | Spacing |
|-------------|----------|--------|
| **Hidden Hangers** | K-style, clean look | 24" OC (18" in snow areas) |
| **Spike & Ferrule** | Old-style, repairs | 24" OC |
| **Strap Hangers** | Half-round, metal roofs | 30" OC |
| **Fascia Brackets** | No fascia board | 24" OC |

> **Zone 6 Critical:** Use 18" hanger spacing in NB to support ice and snow loads. Standard 24" spacing leads to sagging and failure.

### Fascia Board Requirements

**Proper Backing:**
- Fascia must be solid (not rotted)
- Minimum 1" thick nominal lumber
- Paint/prime before gutter installation
- Repair any soft spots

**Drip Edge Integration:**
- Back edge of gutter tucks under drip edge
- Water flows from roof directly into gutter
- No gap between drip edge and gutter back

### End Cap & Seam Sealing

**Sealing Requirements:**
- Apply gutter sealant to all seams
- Both inside and outside of joints
- End caps sealed before installation
- Use silicone or butyl-based sealant

sections.title: Downspouts & Extensions
sections.summary: Installing downspouts, elbows, and extensions for proper water discharge.
sections.content_md:
## Downspouts & Extensions

### Downspout Placement

**Location Guidelines:**
- At low points of gutter runs
- Away from walkways and entries
- Near drainage areas
- Not directly against foundation

**Frequency:**
- One per 40' of gutter (maximum)
- Additional at valleys and corners
- Large roof sections may need more

### Connection to Gutter

**Outlet Installation:**
1. Mark outlet location on gutter bottom
2. Cut hole with snips or hole saw
3. Insert drop outlet from top
4. Crimp tabs and seal joints

**Elbow Configuration:**
- Two elbows typically needed
- "A" elbow at gutter (front-facing)
- "B" elbow at wall (side-facing)
- Short section between elbows

### Securing Downspouts

**Strap Spacing:**
- Top: At elbow connection
- Middle: Every 10 feet
- Bottom: 12" above discharge

**Fastening:**
- Use appropriate fasteners for siding type
- Pre-drill to prevent cracking
- Stainless screws for aluminum downspouts

### Discharge Requirements

**Extensions Minimum:**
- 4 feet from foundation (code minimum)
- 6-10 feet recommended
- Direct to drainage swale if possible

**Extension Options:**

| Type | Pros | Cons |
|------|------|------|
| **Rigid Extension** | Durable, permanent | Visible, trip hazard |
| **Flip-Up** | Folds for mowing | Can get stuck down |
| **Roll-Out** | Auto-deploys | May not roll back |
| **Underground Pipe** | Hidden, effective | Cost, clogging |
| **Splash Block** | Simple, cheap | Minimal protection |

> **Best Practice:** Underground drainage to daylight (exposed pipe away from foundation) is the most reliable solution for NB's heavy rain events.

sections.title: Gutter Guards & Maintenance
sections.summary: Understanding gutter protection options and ongoing maintenance requirements.
sections.content_md:
## Gutter Guards & Maintenance

### Gutter Guard Types

| Type | Description | Effectiveness | Maintenance |
|------|-------------|---------------|-------------|
| **Screen/Mesh** | Metal or plastic grid | Good | Clean screens seasonally |
| **Micro-Mesh** | Fine stainless mesh | Excellent | Brush off debris |
| **Reverse Curve** | Water follows curve, debris falls | Good | May need cleaning inside |
| **Brush Insert** | Bristles fill gutter | Fair | Remove and clean periodically |
| **Foam Insert** | Porous foam block | Poor | Clogs, degrades, replace often |

> **Zone 6 Consideration:** Gutter guards can contribute to ice damming by preventing proper melt drainage. Consider heated cables with guards.

### Regular Maintenance Schedule

**Spring:**
- Clear winter debris
- Check for ice damage
- Verify slope and alignment
- Flush system with hose

**Fall:**
- Remove leaves and debris
- Check and clear downspouts
- Inspect seams and end caps
- Verify extensions in place

**After Storms:**
- Clear debris buildup
- Check for damage
- Verify drainage function

### Cleaning Procedure

1. **Safety First**
   - Stable ladder, proper angle
   - Gloves and eye protection
   - Spotter if possible

2. **Remove Debris**
   - Scoop out by hand or trowel
   - Work toward downspout
   - Bag debris as you go

3. **Flush System**
   - Garden hose from high end
   - Verify water flows to downspout
   - Check for leaks at seams

4. **Clear Downspouts**
   - Flush from top
   - Use plumber's snake if clogged
   - Verify discharge at extension

### Ice Dam Prevention

**Heat Cables:**
- Self-regulating type preferred
- Zigzag pattern along eave edge
- Run through gutters and downspouts
- Thermostat control for efficiency

**Installation Pattern:**
- Loops extend 12-24" up roof
- Cable in gutter bottom
- Down entire downspout length
- Power source with GFCI protection

sections.title: Troubleshooting & Repairs
sections.summary: Diagnosing and fixing common eavestrough problems.
sections.content_md:
## Troubleshooting & Repairs

### Common Problems

**1. Overflowing Gutters**

| Cause | Solution |
|-------|----------|
| Debris buildup | Clean gutters and downspouts |
| Insufficient slope | Re-hang with proper pitch |
| Undersized system | Upgrade to larger gutters/downspouts |
| Too few downspouts | Add additional downspouts |

**2. Leaking Seams**

| Cause | Solution |
|-------|----------|
| Old sealant failure | Clean and re-seal joints |
| Physical damage | Patch or replace section |
| Thermal movement | Use flexible sealant |

**3. Sagging Gutters**

| Cause | Solution |
|-------|----------|
| Hanger spacing too wide | Add intermediate hangers |
| Ice/snow damage | Replace bent sections, add hangers |
| Rotted fascia | Repair fascia, reinstall |

**4. Water Behind Gutter**

| Cause | Solution |
|-------|----------|
| Missing drip edge | Install proper drip edge |
| Gutter too low | Raise gutter to catch drip edge |
| Gap at back | Seal or adjust positioning |

### Repair Techniques

**Sealing Leaks:**
1. Clean area thoroughly (remove old sealant)
2. Dry completely
3. Apply gutter sealant liberally
4. Smooth with gloved finger
5. Allow cure before water exposure

**Patching Holes:**
- Small holes: Roofing cement + mesh patch
- Larger damage: Aluminum patch riveted and sealed
- Severe damage: Replace section

**Re-sloping:**
1. Remove old hangers
2. Mark new slope line
3. Fill old screw holes
4. Install new hangers along line
5. Verify water flow

### When to Replace

**Signs It's Time:**
- Multiple sections with holes
- Extensive rust (steel gutters)
- Severe sagging throughout
- Seams pulling apart repeatedly
- Paint peeling/chalking severely

> **Upgrade Tip:** When replacing, consider upgrading to seamless gutters. More expensive initially but fewer leak points and longer lifespan.

questions.question: What is the minimum eavestrough slope toward the downspout?
questions.explanation: Minimum slope is 1/16" per foot, though 1/8" per foot is recommended for heavy rain areas.

questions.question: What is the recommended hanger spacing for Zone 6?
questions.explanation: 18" hanger spacing is recommended for Zone 6 to support ice and snow loads. Standard 24" often leads to sagging.

questions.question: What is the maximum gutter run length to a single downspout?
questions.explanation: Maximum gutter run to a single downspout is 40 feet. Longer runs need additional downspouts.

questions.question: What is the minimum downspout extension distance from the foundation?
questions.explanation: Minimum extension is 4 feet from foundation (code minimum), though 6-10 feet is recommended.

questions.question: Which gutter material should be avoided in NB due to cold brittleness?
questions.explanation: Vinyl becomes brittle in cold temperatures and should be avoided in NB's Zone 6 climate.

questions.question: What size gutter is recommended for roof areas over 1000 sq ft?
questions.explanation: 6" K-style gutters are recommended for roof areas over 1000 square feet to handle the increased water volume.

questions.question: Where should the back edge of the gutter be positioned?
questions.explanation: The back edge of the gutter should tuck under the drip edge so water flows directly into the gutter.

questions.question: How often should gutters be cleaned in a typical year?
questions.explanation: Gutters should be cleaned twice a year - in spring after winter debris and in fall after leaves drop.

questions.question: What is the most reliable solution for water discharge in heavy rain areas?
questions.explanation: Underground drainage to daylight (exposed pipe away from foundation) is the most reliable solution for heavy rain events.

questions.question: What type of heat cable is preferred for ice dam prevention?
questions.explanation: Self-regulating heat cables are preferred as they automatically adjust output based on temperature.

questions.question: What causes water to flow behind the gutter instead of into it?
questions.explanation: Water behind the gutter is typically caused by missing drip edge, gutter too low, or improper gap at the back.

questions.question: What is a potential issue with gutter guards in Zone 6?
options: They can contribute to ice damming
questions.explanation: Gutter guards can contribute to ice damming by preventing proper melt drainage. Heat cables may be needed with guards.

questions.question: When repairing a leaking seam, what is the first step?
options: Clean area and remove old sealant
Install a patch over the seam
questions.explanation: The first step is to clean the area thoroughly and remove old sealant before applying new sealant.

questions.question: What type of gutter profile handles the most water?
questions.explanation: Box/commercial profile gutters have maximum capacity and are used for large roof areas.

questions.question: What should be done with old screw holes when re-sloping gutters?
questions.explanation: Old screw holes should be filled before installing new hangers in new locations to maintain fascia integrity.
